**Rogue One – 4 Stars** As a huge Star Wars nerd, *Rogue One* had me hooked from day one. I remember watching it in theaters, jaw dropped. After binging *Andor*, it only made sense to revisit this gem. The cast? Spot on. The atmosphere and worldbuilding scream classic Star Wars but with a grittier, grounded vibe that just works. Seeing the Death Star’s power firsthand while still planet-side? Absolutely intense and terrifying in the best way. Ben Mendelsohn as Krennic nails it as a smug yet desperate villain, but let’s be honest—Darth Vader steals the show. That hallway scene? *Chef’s kiss*. He’s never looked more menacing. The cinematography is top-notch, making this feel like a proper war movie in space. This is exactly how you expand the universe: new stories that respect the old while pushing things forward. *Rogue One* bridges perfectly into *A New Hope*. Loved it.

"Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" is a dramatic and thrilling entry in the Star Wars universe that stands out as a unique and powerful bridge into one of the greatest trilogies of all time. With strong performances and gripping action, the film delivers a well-crafted narrative centered on sacrifice, hope, and the cost of freedom. Unlike many other entries in the saga, Rogue One has the strength to stand on its own, offering a rich and transformative story that deepens the meaning of the rebellion and what it truly means to fight for something greater than yourself.

I grew up a Star Wars nerd...so this is written as both a fan and as a filmmaker, writer, and story teller. So maybe my film knowledge will balance out the fandom. I've always wanted to see a more raw, grounded, gritty Star Wars film not built for kids, but built to make a fictional universe truly alive. Rogue One nails that. So regardless of critics and reviews, there is one pure element that can't be denied. Rogue One is the closest Star Wars has ever gotten to feeling like a tangible, living, existing thing. It's a natural fan evolution: from a kid that likes laser swords, to an adult that realizes laser swords could exist. To echo our own society and culture, this is Star Wars keeping it real. The story fills previous lore gaps when it comes to the Death Star, much of the rebel workings, and how the Death Star was so easily destroyed. This alone, makes the original Star Wars film richer and stronger. It also features no Jedi but manages to make The Force still important. It features a droid - quite the opposite of the typical cliche - that keeps the connection of flesh and metal intact. And while Darth Vader is a legend...this is the first film after his transition that truly shows how deadly, cold, capable, and legendary he is. That alone is worth 4 stars out of 5 to me. The uninitiated might not understand that and should educate themselves before they give a low score. His five minutes to the knowledgeable fan make the film at least 3 to 4 stars. The use of old unused footage to tie it to the original Star Wars is pure genius as well and the third act action delivers like Postmates. Chris Weltz and Tony Gilroy did a hell of a job writing it, and Gareth Edwards killed it. The dialogue, feel, and texture of the film, for me, was something I dreamed of but didn't think was possible. They even brought in space martial arts, which alone, should garner the film an additional star. And they didn't need a Jedi to save the film, or make it flounder like the "forced" (pun intended) sequel trilogy. This is the rawest Star Wars film you're ever going to get. Most-likely...EVER No agendas except handling the mission for the people. Add a star for that. The Andor series by Gilroy, and with the same aesthetic and exploration of both Star Wars realism and choosing to dive deeper, has received the most acclaim out of ANY Star Wars project since. There's a reason for that. That also should earn a star. ...and yes, the CGI Tarkin and Leia isn't perfect. But that can be fixed in the future. What should impress you, is that the filmmakers felt them necessary to tell the proper story so they did what they had to do. If you're looking at Rogue One holistically...in terms of story, aesthetic, acting, writing, directing, cinematography, production, closing up old story holes, making Stars Wars more grounded and realistic, innovating, elevating, making a funny robot also a killing machine, giving the best Darth Vader moment ever...and everybody dies?!?! And if after all of that, it's not at least four stars out of five? The Force isn't with you. And that's okay. I'd recommend starting with The Last Jedi. That will probably be your cup of tea.

My chronological rewatch of the films continues, and watching them this way really highlights what a good film this is - in terms of the timeline, the first film that feels coherent and, well, good. A fine cast is well directed by Gareth Edwards, who has a flair for science fiction action adventure and an eye for a striking image. It has wit, energy, focus, good humour, spectacle, and fun. There's an argument that the Star Wars films are mostly aimed at younger audiences; if that's true, then this film may be seen to stray from that. But I'd like to think younger audiences will also appreciate this for what it is - a well-constructed war adventure with sleek narrative lines and a smattering of all the important constituent parts along the way. Think how much this film's timeline predecessors would be appreciated if the care that characterises Rogue One had been taken on them.

Like so many others, I grew up on the original trilogy (IV-VI). Pre- Hayden Christensen Anakin, pre- special edition. They are the movies that created the world and sucked millions (billions?) into it. That said, after many re-watches of all 11 movies, I’ve concluded that the final 40 minutes of Rogue One is the absolute best of Star Wars. It feels like a successful marriage of the optimism and excitement of A New Hope, the drama of The Empire Strikes Back, the desperation and triumph of Return Of the Jedi, the storytelling of the prequels, the nostalgia of Solo, and the visuals of the Disney trilogy. A phenomenal cast, authentic heroes/heroines and villains, and the ability to capture the spirit of Star Wars WITHOUT A SINGLE JEDI is magnificent. It’s all there, and the final moments include an incredible showcase of the true terror of Darth Vader seen in no other movie, concluded by a masterful hand-off of the story to Episode IV that cries perfection.

Among all the movies I’ve seen, "Rogue One" stands out as one of my favorites. As a fan of the Star Wars universe, this installment offers me an authentic and exciting experience. The film features stunning landscapes, and the cinematography is one of its great strengths. Each frame is designed to immerse us in the distant galaxy we love so much. The special effects are outstanding, contributing to the spectacle of the action scenes. The story keeps you glued to the screen, as it connects episodes III and IV in a smart way, even though it’s a standalone film. It’s not strictly necessary to watch it to understand the saga, but it’s definitely an excellent gateway for those looking to dive deeper into Star Wars lore. One of the best parts of the movie is the third act, which is full of suspense, action, and both aerial and ground battles. However, while I enjoyed the story, I have to mention that the development of the main character didn’t entirely convince me; there were aspects of her story that felt a bit too convenient. Speaking of the story, I really liked the performances of the leads. Among them, my favorite is Diego Luna, who plays a Rebel spy. His character development is one of the highlights of the story. K-2SO, the reprogrammed Imperial droid, also shines; he gained personality as a side effect of his reprogramming and is a sarcastic character who made me laugh out loud more than once. Jyn Erso, the protagonist, also has a memorable story, although there are a couple of things that didn’t convince me, such as her joining the Rebellion, which felt too easy or convenient for the plot. Still, her development is generally acceptable. As for the other three members of the squad, they don’t appear much on screen and seemed a bit forgettable; I’d almost say they were included just to support the continuation of the story. Despite this, "Rogue One" is a film that I definitely recommend to any Star Wars fan. It offers an exciting and visually impactful experience that you won’t want to miss.

Rogue One is a surprise diamond in the rough. Though the film lacks the flair (minimal lightsabers) and wit (barely any humor) of other Star Wars films, it fits the narrative being told. The cinematography is Rogue One is crisp and the dialogue is generally pretty good. The tone is serious and the characters fully embrace the severity of the situation. There are duller moments, particularly in the first two acts, but the story comes full circle in the end. I've said it before and I'll say it again, Star Wars knows how to execute killer third acts. The finale of this film is no different, and might be the best climax in the franchise other than RoTS. Everything that happens after the shield opens on Scarif is anxiety inducing. Though we have a short time to develop relationships with these characters, the connections are strong as we watch their fight for hope. Rogue One is one of those movies that did not need to be made, but I am glad that it was. I try to stray away from using the word "perfect" in these reviews, but this film is the perfect segue into the original trilogy. Best Character: Cassian Andor Best Moment: The Vader slaughter. Best Quote: "It's not a problem if you don't look up." That was Jyn's response when asked about the Empire's rule and the Imperial flag flying. This single line adds needed depth and understanding to her character.

"Rogue One: A Star Wars Story," directed by Gareth Edwards and released in 2016, stands out as a bold and compelling entry in the Star Wars franchise. As the first of the standalone anthology films, it carves its own path while seamlessly integrating into the broader Star Wars mythology. With its gritty tone, complex characters, and breathtaking visuals, "Rogue One" delivers a powerful and emotionally resonant story of courage and sacrifice. Set just before the events of "A New Hope," "Rogue One" fills in the crucial backstory of how the Rebel Alliance acquired the Death Star plans, setting the stage for the original trilogy. The film introduces us to Jyn Erso (Felicity Jones), a fierce and determined heroine whose personal vendetta against the Empire becomes a catalyst for a larger rebellion. Jones' performance is compelling, imbuing Jyn with both vulnerability and strength, making her journey deeply affecting. The ensemble cast of "Rogue One" is exceptional, bringing to life a diverse group of characters, each with their own unique motivations and arcs. Diego Luna’s Cassian Andor is a complex figure, a Rebel intelligence officer who operates in the moral gray areas of wartime. Donnie Yen’s Chirrut Îmwe and Jiang Wen’s Baze Malbus provide a dynamic duo, blending spirituality and brute force, while Riz Ahmed’s Bodhi Rook offers a portrayal of redemption and bravery. Alan Tudyk’s K-2SO, a reprogrammed Imperial droid, injects the film with much-needed humor and heart, his dry wit and loyalty making him an unforgettable character. Mads Mikkelsen’s portrayal of Galen Erso, Jyn's father and the reluctant architect of the Death Star, adds a layer of emotional complexity to the narrative. His internal struggle and ultimate act of defiance against the Empire provide a poignant underpinning to the story. Ben Mendelsohn’s Orson Krennic, the ambitious and ruthless Imperial Director, serves as a formidable antagonist whose pursuit of power adds to the film’s tension and stakes. Visually, "Rogue One" is stunning. Gareth Edwards' direction brings a sense of scale and realism to the Star Wars universe, with striking cinematography that captures both the grandeur of space battles and the gritty, war-torn landscapes of planets like Jedha and Scarif. The film’s special effects are top-notch, seamlessly blending practical and digital elements to create immersive and believable environments. The film’s score, composed by Michael Giacchino, pays homage to John Williams’ iconic themes while introducing new motifs that enhance the story’s epic and emotional moments. The music supports the narrative beautifully, from the suspenseful heist sequences to the somber and reflective moments of sacrifice and loss. "Rogue One" excels in its portrayal of the moral complexities and harsh realities of rebellion. The film does not shy away from showing the difficult choices and sacrifices that come with fighting an oppressive regime. The climactic battle on Scarif is a masterclass in tension and action, culminating in a bittersweet victory that underscores the film’s themes of hope and sacrifice. The visceral, ground-level perspective of the conflict brings a fresh and intense energy to the Star Wars saga. The film’s connection to "A New Hope" is handled with care and respect, culminating in a seamless transition that enhances both films. The appearance of Darth Vader, particularly in the chilling hallway scene, serves as a powerful reminder of his terrifying presence and the looming threat of the Empire. In conclusion, "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" is a standout addition to the Star Wars canon, offering a gripping and emotionally charged narrative that enriches the overall saga. Its blend of strong performances, stunning visuals, and a compelling story of heroism and sacrifice makes it a must-watch for fans and newcomers alike. "Rogue One" is a testament to the enduring power of the Star Wars universe, proving that even in the darkest of times, hope can prevail.

In all seriousness, this is indeed one of the best Star Wars movies out there, especially when it takes war much more serious. Now, as the story goes, a great one when outside of the Jedi and every main character we know and love, except a couple which I'll keep to myself. The acting does range from amazing when it comes to emotional moments, serious moments and how it drives the plot to decent when the movie does have to take a breath, which I don't mind it that much. My favorites do have to be K-2SO and Chirrut Imwe, while everyone else are great on their own when the story has to advance from scene to scene even from Jyn and Cassian's point of view. The scenery does look great, I would have to say the best out of every live-action Star Wars movies. The action does fit the greatest since this is more of an actual war movie when getting the plans of the Death Star to fighting off Stormtroopers to at the least, fight in a war. Even as watching this first time, I do see why most fans see this as one of the best. Even gets you on the edge of your seat and see where all this goes before the climax, which is a little slow, but it is what it is. Some find it okay, some find it amazing. I do stand by saying, this was, once again, not just a Star Wars movie, but a great war movie on it's own. 9/10.

The best Star Wars movie since Revenge of the Sith, this first entry in the anthology films captures the flair of the original trilogy. The characters are likable, the action is brisk, and the Empire hasn't been this intimidating since The Empire Strikes Back. Out of all the movies that have been released by Disney after they bought Lucasfilm, this is one of the few things that have felt like a Star Wars movie. I appreciate the darker tone, while it still has some great jokes sprinkled in, mostly from K2-SO, who gave me some of the biggest laughs in the movie, while not just being a quip machine, like a lot of Disney SW characters. Every character feels like they exist in this world, and I especially like Beize and Chirrut's dynamic. They feel like true friends, willing to stick by one another, despite having differences in what they believe. Cassian Andor (with the benefit of watching the Andor series) is one of the best characters, and making him out to be a more morally grey character really shows how the SW universe is full of lawlessness, even in characters who we should see as the heroes. The special effects are some of the best I've seen in a Star Wars film, and every ship and planet feels photoreal. However, the digital doubles for Tarkin and Leia don't work very well, and while Tarkin as a fully CG human character is impressive, it still carries the stench of uncanniness. Another character I don't really care for is Bodhi, the pilot. He doesn't really have much to do, or much of a character, and when he gets his little moment to shine, he dies immediately after. Other than that, this is a great Star Wars film, and the last hour brings us some of the greatest, most inventive battle sequences in any of the films, with with some good characters, and a slow-building yet engaging story. If you haven't seen this, I encourage you to give it a shot.

While Disney's Star Wars hasn't seen the greatest days, there are still indeed some gems in a world of stone, and Rogue One: A Star Wars Story is absolutely one of them. Having such a smart premise and execution, doing a service to all the nit-pickers of A New Hope and giving us a new invigorating story that gives us an expansive refined context on A New Hope that I can't help but praise.

10/10 Sem duvidas o melhor filme de Star Wars "Rogue One: Uma História Star Wars" é uma adição notável ao universo cinematográfico de Star Wars, oferecendo uma aventura épica repleta de ação que certamente se destaca entre as melhores cenas de ação de toda a franquia. As cenas de ação em Rogue One são de tirar o fôlego e estão entre as melhores do universo cinematográfico de Star Wars. Desde batalhas explosivas no espaço até combates intensos em terra, o filme oferece uma variedade de sequências de ação emocionantes e bem coreografadas. A habilidade da direção em capturar a grandiosidade e o perigo das batalhas é impressionante, mantendo os espectadores na ponta de suas cadeiras durante toda a projeção. Além da ação espetacular, Rogue One também apresenta personagens cativantes e bem desenvolvidos. Jyn Erso, interpretada brilhantemente por Felicity Jones, é uma protagonista carismática e determinada, cuja jornada pessoal é emocionante de acompanhar. Os demais membros do grupo de rebeldes também têm suas oportunidades de brilhar, com destaque para o carismático Cassian Andor, o sarcástico K-2SO e o misterioso Chirrut Îmwe.

One of the best Star Wars movies ever made. Right up there with Empire Strikes back. Has its moments, I understand where people come from when they claim this is the best of the 'Disney era' of Star Wars films. But given its self-contained nature, relatively simple premise and how it ends, I think it either lacks characters to invest in, or there simply isn't enough background on all of them to make it feel satisfying. It does feature an excellent score without Williams at the helm, which does its own thing while drawing from the classics you would expect to hear in a movie like this. The cast is generally great. It does its own thing while also doing what it can to connect to the films we all know by now, which usually works within the plot well. Give it a watch if you like the original trilogy and prequel trilogy but are less so keen on the sequels, it is cut from a different cloth.

The first and one of two "A Star Wars Story" movies made by Disney. Rogue One is a fantastic movie that gives context to how the rebellion was able to retrieve the Death Star plans in the original movie. The main stand out for the movie is its fantastic writing from Tony Gilroy. He does a great job at introducing completely unknown characters and making them an interesting part of the story. Jyn Erso, Cassian Andor, Galen Erso and the rest of "Rogue One" are intriguing to me. The world-building is very good and introduced us to the world of Star Wars right before the Battle of Yavin. Not only is the writing fantastic, the filmmaking is very good. There are some incredible shots to look at. The cinematography is just very good. The musical score is amazing and the sound design always give me chills. The action is brutal and is something I would love to see more of in Star Wars. Overall, Rogue One is a fantastic entry into the Star Wars universe that tells a beautifully crafted story about the Rebellion.

Best of the Disney-era Star Wars movies. Here Star Wars feels like a real war movie, complete with tough moral choices and tragic losses. I'll admit I've never been one especially keen on Star Wars films. I have seen a couple previously but I can't claim to have fully followed the plot intricacies. I heard this film was recommended, even to non-Star Wars fans, however, so I decided to give it a go. Its certainly not a bad film - its reasonably tense and atmospheric at times and it is somewhat gripping as well, with good chase scenes. There's a decent cast present too, including Forest Whitaker and Mads Mikkelsen, among others. Its pretty entertaining and I thought the special effects were well done but its very much a sci-fi film and the plot is somewhat complicated. I'm pretty s ure you can enjoy it, even if you don't pay much attention to every last plot point, however. Its not the sort of film I think I'd want to watch again but its certainly a good film and so I'd say its worth seeing if it interests you, or if your a sci-fi fan, then yes I would recommend it. I can think of worse ways to spend a little over 2 hours, though it isn't exactly greatly meaningful or memorable, its definitely not bad either and does a good job of keeping the viewer entertained, even if said viewer may not be entirely sure of everything going on. Sometimes escapism is all thats needed in a film, especially these days.

Very Good Action Sequences and Very Good Cinematography Overall with Very Good Special Effects. The soundtrack was phenomenal as well. The movie had a good pacing as well. The plot is easy to follow as well. My main problem consistently throughout this film was outside of the main protagonist to a degree I felt every single character in this was very generic lacking any real identity or charisma. It felt like the writers didn't feel there was a need to flesh these characters out hardly at all because they all suffer the same fate but that isn't an excuse for lazy writing. And because of that that is why the acting also feels like its nothing special either. The actors aren't given much to work with except be likeable and accouple of quirks that are I guess meant to substitute for personality. Acting and the Characters were the main problems I had with this consistently. And it really starts to weigh the longer things go on. But still every other element is very well done especially a very well done action packed ending. This is a classic of its franchise and if your a fan of Star wars you'll like it it is definitely worth at least one viewing but this isn't anywhere near the quality of the original trilogy because of the lack of rich characters.

Rogue One is hands down, the best Star Wars movie in the Disney era and is on par with the quality of the original trilogy. Everything from the cast, the overall/original storyline and character progression is exceptional. Even small wins, like opening the shields, felt so significant in this movie and for the first time, the feeling of dread and terror was ever presence. The cast/characters - particularly in the second half of this film - were so likeable because of their arcs and genuine bravery. There was no plot armor, no character was safe from demise, yet, they sacrificed everything for information that gave them nothing more than a mere chance of survival. The closing Vadar scene also culminated the quality of cast and story. The extras who played the Rebels put in such an incredible performance during that final scene. The feeling of sheer horror when Vadar's lightsaber shone was totally unlike anything I'd felt while watching a movie. The "LAUNCH" scream from one the rebels highlighted how terrifying and evil Vadar had become. It also gave 'A New Hope' so much more meaning which is quite a feat. They HAD to succeed in their mission after the Rebels gave up their own lives to get the Death Star plans. Jyn was perfectly cast and an example of how to write a strong female character. She was so easy to like, her script was brilliant and she was the consummate hero. Jyn was arguably the most important "side story" (for lack of a better term) in all of Star Wars. This is an absolute must watch for all Star Wars fans. 11/10
